item.title: Your favorite band has a new single? It might be AI
item.description: With AI music generators widely available, scammers are uploading songs to the pages of inactive artists and dead musicians. Spotify says it is cracking down, but the practice persists.

item.title: Boost hope and reduce stress with this simple social media trick
item.description: Social media can push us to the dark side with negative content. A new study finds watching inspiring videos for just three minutes a day can boost your mood and reduce stress.

item.title: A Confederate statue toppled in Washington, D.C., in 2020 has been reinstalled
item.description: A statue of Confederate general Albert Pike, which had been pulled down during the Black Lives Matter movement, has been put back up in Washington, D.C.'s Judiciary Square.

item.title: In Cameroon, the world's oldest leader claims victory -- again
item.description: 92-year- old Paul Biya, the world's oldest head of state, claims victory in a disputed election, sparking unrest across the country already grappling with violence, corruption, and political tension.

item.title: 'Trapped and terrified': warnings as Sudanese militia advance on Darfur city
item.description: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces claim they've seized the Sudanese army's last base in El Fasher, Darfur — trapping hundreds of thousands and stoking fears the country could split in two.

item.description: Ireland's president for the next seven years is an independent lawmaker who has long spoken in support of Palestinians and has been vocal about her distrust of European Union policies.

item.title: Finland's stubbornly low birth rate shows why a population shift may be inevitable
item.description: Famous for baby boxes and expansive pro-family policies, Finland continues to see one of the lowest birth rates in Europe, as a case study in how policy solutions may not address the population shift.
